item.title: Linear Stepper to Operate Turnouts
item.description: After being a bit disappointed with both my muscle wire and servo experiments to operate turnouts, I started doing a bit of research on linear actuators. While most were very expensive, I eventually stumbled on some at AliExpress by searching for the term ‘Miniature Slide Screw Stepper’ or ‘linear stepper’ and various combinations of similar words. item.title: Dremel Tool Turnout Jig
item.description: As mentioned in my last post, I have discovered that a Dremel type moto-tool makes an excellent point shaping tool for constructing model railroad turnouts. Combined with the simple jig below I found the process to be much easier and faster than the traditional filing method.
item.dc:creator: John Appleseed

item.title: Turnouts 4 and 5
item.description: A few days after that router episode I hit on the idea of using my Dremel Tool to grind the turnout points. I probably would have thought of it earlier but I only just got the Dremel for Christmas and wasn’t really familiar with it. I quickly grabbed a short piece of rail, put it in a vice and stuck a No. 409 grinding disk into the Dremel. Success! Time to make another jig!
item.dc:creator: John Appleseed

item.title: A Turnout Jig
item.description: After building 3 turnouts I have been thinking a bit on how to speed up their construction. By far the slowest - and hardest - part is filing the 2 switch rail points and a corresponding notch on the stock rails. It’s also quite stressful and easy to mess up.
item.dc:creator: John Appleseed

item.description: In my last post I mentioned that I now have 2 Arduino controller boards for experimenting with creating my own DCC command station, booster and DCC decoder.
